Chemistry

is one of the most important and extensive fields of natural science, the science that studies substances, also their composition and structure, and their properties. And this science has many connections with physics and biology. It also studies the transformation of one or more initial substances (reactants) into other substances, so-called chemical reactions.
roman_ship_2
Chemistry is the science that studies the structure and properties of matter, and all the changes that happen to it, but what's the point? Why do we need it? Why do we need this knowledge?

Chemistry plays a key role in the food industry, ensuring that raw materials are transformed into delicious and safe dishes. For example Salt, whose crystals we grew in our reactions section, is a natural preservative that allows food to keep longer and acquire new flavors.

Now our turn

Atoms are the fundamental building blocks of all matter, and they retain the properties of the element they represent. And all atoms really consists of electrons, protons and neutrons. The only except is hydrogenium-1 (also protium, model given below), which has no neutrons. Neutrons üü° is electoneutral.
hydrogen_atom_model

If the number of electrons üîµ (- charged) matches the number of protons üî¥ (+ charged) in the nucleus, the atom is considered electrically neutral. Otherwise it is called an ion and has some positive (called cation) or negative charge (called anion).

Almost all of the mass of an atom is made up of the nucleus, at least 99.9% of it, which consists of protons üî¥ and neutrons üü° linked together by strong interactions. The rest of atomic mass of the element is reserved for electrons üîµ that surround the nucleus.
lithium_atom_model
But how to count all these particles?

We don't have to calculate them manually on the atomic model. (We certainly don't forbid you to do this, moreover, we recommend that you verify this yourself.) It's enough to just remember a few tricks.

The number of
protons üî¥
corresponds to the atomic number of the atom in the periodic table.

The number of
neutrons üü°
just subtract the atomic number from the atomic mass number of the element.

The number of
electrons üîµ
in an electrically neutral atom corresponds to the atomic number of the atom in the periodic table (also equal the number of protons).

Isotopes

The number of protons determines its belonging to a certain chemical element, and the number of neutrons corresponds to a certain isotope of this element. A variant of an element that has the same number of protons üî¥ but a different number of neutrons üü° in the nucleus, resulting in different properties while still belonging to the same element, is called an isotope. We'll talk about isotopes later in other lessons.
But how are these particles arranged?

If positioning the nucleus is clear, it is located in the center üéØ of the atom, like the pith in a peachüçë, then we want to know more about positioning the electrons üîµ that ‚Äúsurround or orbit‚Äù around this nucleus.
Let's dive into history of understanding how atoms looks like
Ancient Greece

Already in 5th century BC, Leucippus and his talanted student Democritus anounced the idea that all matter was composed of small, invisible to the human eye, indivisible particles which they called ‚Äúatoms‚Äù. Also they suposed that nature consists of two fundamental principles: atom and void. According to their theory, atoms are constantly moving, floating in the omnipresent void, and colliding with each other. These ideas formed the basis of the theory of atomism.
democritus

Democritus belived that some atoms, he maintained, are convex, others concave, some shaped like hooks, and others like eyes. He alseo believed that the properties of a substance were determined by the shape, mass, and other characteristics of the atoms that formed it. Thus, for example, fire has sharp atoms, so the fire is able to burn, in solids they are rough, so they firmly adhere to each other, in water - smooth, so it is able to flow.
Solid sphere
solid_sphere

In 1803, the English chemist John Dalton drew on the ideas of the ancient Greeks to describe atoms as small, solid spheres that are inseparable and that the atoms of a given element are identical to each other. He also suposed that atoms has no any charge.
dalton_elements

On the picture you can see the Symbols of elements and Dalton's estimates of their atomic masses. He came up with theories about how atoms combine to make compounds, and also came up with the first set of chemical symbols for known elements.
J.J.Thomson discovered the existence of the electron üîµ
Plum pudding model
pudding_model

Shortly after the discovery of the electron, but before the discovery of the atomic nucleus, J.J.Thomson in 1904 proposed to consider the atom as a kind of positively charged spherical body ‚Äúpudding‚Äù with electrons ‚Äúraisins‚Äù enclosed inside it.
pudding_model_schematically

Thomson guessed that atoms must also have a source of positive charge to balance the negative charge of the electrons, but the nucleus had not yet been discovered. He also argued that electrons were free to spin in circular orbits inside the positively charged substance.
Nuclear model

Ernest Rutherford in 1911 suggested that the charge of atoms is concentrated in a very small nucleus. And that an atom consists of a positively charged nucleus with electrons orbiting around it. He did not discuss the organization of electrons in the atom's shells or orbits, by his theory electrons orbiting in arbitrary orbits.
rutherford_atom_model
We have already seen something similar when we counted the number of electrons üîµ, protons üî¥ and neutrons üü°.
Rutherford came to this conclusion from an experiment in which he fired positively charged alpha particles into a thin sheet of gold foil.
rutherford_experiment

The alpha particles were small enough to pass through the gold foil, and according to Thomson's model, which showed a positive charge scattered throughout the atom, they should do so with little or no deflection. Rutherford's analysis proposed a high central charge concentrated into a very small volume in comparison to the rest of the atom. (Rutherford's model of the atom on the plane given below.)
rutherford_atom_model_2
Alpha particle - a positively charged particle formed by two protons and two neutrons; the nucleus of the helium-4 atom. First discovered by Ernest Rutherford in 1899.
Planetary model

In 1913, physicist Niels Bohr proposed a new model in which the electrons of an atom were thought to orbit the nucleus, but could only occupy a limited set of orbits. They could jump between these orbits only with discrete changes in energy, corresponding to the absorption or emission of a photon.
lithium_planetary_model

The figure above shows a planetary model of a lithium atom, which contains a positively charged nucleus and 3 negatively charged electrons, 2 of which orbit in the first orbit (shell) and the last in the second orbit (shell). As we said earlier, Bohr's model suggested the existence of energy levels or shells for electrons. Electrons could only be located in these specific energy levels; in other words, their energy was quantized (i.e., strictly defined) and could not assume any arbitrary value.

The nuclear model (Rutherford) and the planetary (Bohr) model of the atom are not the same, though they are related. The nuclear model, proposed by Rutherford, describes the atom as having a small, dense, positively charged nucleus with electrons orbiting around it. The planetary model, specifically Bohr's model, expands on this by specifying that electrons orbit in specific, quantized energy levels or shells, like planets orbiting the sun.
Rutherford discovered the existence of the proton üî¥
Quantum model

In 1926, Erwin Schr√∂dinger proposed that electrons do not travel in fixed paths around the nucleus; instead, they behave like waves. We cannot determine the exact position of the electrons; rather, we have 'probability clouds' known as orbitals, where the likelihood of finding an electron is greater. He describes electrons as three-dimensional waveforms rather than points in space.
shredinger_cat
We all know how Schr√∂dinger liked to ‚Äúformulate‚Äù his thoughts, and although this model of the atom is difficult to illustrate, we have attempted to do so.
shredinger_model
Schr√∂dinger was not interested in the nucleus of the atom itself. But, by the way, at the time of work on this model, it was not yet realized that the nucleus had neutrons.
James Chadwick (a student of Rutherford) discovered the existence of the neutron üü°
So after that moment, mankind learned that the nucleus is made up of a proton üî¥ and a neutron üü°.

The nucleus is very small compared to the size of an atom (about 10,000 to 100,000 times), and although it is most often in the shape of a sphere or ellipsoid, more complex geometries can be observed in some cases.
nucleus_model

What is the best model to use you may ask? Not so long ago mankind was content with the raisin pudding model and all was well, no one was hurt. Of course, we would like to get into the truest and most correct model the first time, but historical hindsight shows that even quite stable theories turn out to be false.

The situation is complicated by the incomplete knowledge of the properties of the nuclear forces and the fact that the nucleons themselves are also composite particles (they consist of quarks).

But we believe that one day we will be able to safely saw the atom into small pieces, so to speak skillfully disassemble it into its component screws.

For example

The planetary model of an atom, often called the mechanical model, is used to simplify the representation of an atom, mainly to demonstrate the basic principles of structure and interaction.
The quantum model, on the contrary, is more accurate and complex, describing the behavior of electrons in an atom using quantum mechanical laws.
The mechanical model is used for initial understanding, and the quantum model is used for deeper study.
